content:
Yes, but you have to deal with this. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/dedicated-profile-thunderbird-installation

You also need to be aware that each version contains many bug fixes and security fixes. https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/security/known-vulnerabilities/thunderbird/

Going backwards is largely asking for trouble, hence many like myself remain on the ESR release which updates once a year, gets those security fixes and does not have as many issues with addons not being updated before the monthly release makes it obsolete.

You actually get to choose to use/download the ESR version here https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/ the big bold download button on the main page will always offer the monthly release.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
FIXED

1. Close Thunderbird: Make sure the application is completely closed.

2. Locate your Profile Folder: C:\Users\[Your_Username]\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\

3. Find the profiles.ini file: Inside your Thunderbird profiles directory, locate the profiles.ini file. This file lists all your Thunderbird profiles.

4. Find the correct profile folder: The profiles.ini file will show you the name of your profile folder, which is typically a string of random letters and numbers followed by .default-release (e.g., abcdefgh.default-release). Go into that folder.

5. Delete the residual information in the file: Inside your profile folder, look for a file named prefs.js (BACKUP FIRST) and open it with a text editor. Search for your email address or the domain of your email provider. You are looking for a line that starts with something like user_pref("mail.server.serverX.hostname", ...); where X is a number. This line holds the incoming server information that is causing the conflict. Carefully delete the entire block of lines related to your email account. It will be a set of lines with mail.server.serverX and mail.account.accountX that match your email. If you're not comfortable editing the file, you can try deleting the entire file, but this will reset other preferences as well.

My X = 3 user_pref("mail.server.server3.check_new_mail", true); user_pref("mail.server.server3.clientid", … user_pref("mail.server.server3.directory", … user_pref("mail.server.server3.directory-rel… user_pref("mail.server.server3.hostname", … ...

Best regards, Jose
creator: jose_ze

content:
As Thunderbird simply does not offer mail accounts, anything you add will by definition have to already exist. Like so many stupid things in computing Thunderbird used to try an make an delineation between the accounts that were offered as "new" under a commercial arrangement and those that you already have. As that relationship has apparently ended, the links in the menu no longer exist, there is nothing to delineate. I doubt a great deal of though went into the change as the Project will be offering it's own "New" email addresses as a part of the Thundermail initiative so another batch of changes are only a matter of a short time away.

So use the menu

or you might use the New account button in account settings.

Neither creates a new email address, only being able to add an existing email account to the mail client.

content:
DO not use the export. Try these steps that work: Here is the link for moving a profile in Windows when installed in default location: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there

content:
Tools | Account Settings | + New Account | Mail Account

That fires up a Wizard that will prompt you for the basic information. It queries its own database of known email hosts and will probably be able to fill in the necessary (IMAP/POP and SMTP) server settings. It would be best if you come armed with that information, just in case you need it.

content:
Go to Tools | Account Settings for the account in question. At the bottom of that main page, there's a button labeled "Manage Identities" There you can add, edit and delete identities and designate one as the default.

When you're writing or replying to a message, you'll find a down arrow by the From slot - dropping that down you can choose from all the various identities you've created. If you don't choose a different one, the default one will be used.

content: Matt has given you good information. It's possible that you have set at least one of your two programs to download mail from the server and then delete it from the server. content:
Hi ksmith. Thanks for sharing the screenshots. Your second one shows that your account is set up in Thunderbird as an IMAP account. Now we need to know if your account is set up in Outlook as an IMAP account or a POP account. As Lin, I am not (no longer) familiar with Outlook, so I cannot tell you where to look.

AI says:

  1. Open Outlook on your computer.
  2. Navigate to the File tab.
  3. Click on Account Settings, and then select Account Settings again from the dropdown menu.
  4. In the Accounts box, look at the left pane and click on the specific account you want to check.
  5. The type of account (e.g., Exchange, IMAP, or POP) will be displayed at the top of the right pane.

Alternatively, for Outlook Web App, you can often find POP and IMAP settings by going to Settings > Mail > Sync email.

creator: ksmith26

content:
I would open that filter by pressing the "Edit" button and see what it does. Would you please post a screenshot of the filter rules?

If that filter is not the cause of the problem, I would start Windows in safe mode with networking, then start Thunderbird in troubleshooting mode (Help menu), and see if the problem occurs.

Anti-virus software creates problems for Thunderbird. A common recommendation on this forum is to create exceptions for Thunderbird in the anti-virus program. I cannot guide you in doing that.

content:
What font do you use? I really think it is probably something the council does not have, so it is being displayed with the next best character set they have.

I used to see it a fair bit when folk used windows XP era fonts (TTF) when the rest of the world is not using Unicode fonts. Things like Arial cause real issues like this as well as most of the fonts release with word processors before about 2016.

I have also seen it when folks use Apple specific fonts to send mail read on windows and when they compose in their word processor and copy and paste into Thunderbird to send.

HTML, which is how email is actually sent used a fallback process when fonts are specified. sometime the text has a series of fallback font listed, but that is generally when the professional have crafted a web site. Automatic fallback fonts can be ugly because the fallback is often to some default root, either san serif font or a serif font depending on which is specified.

This page contains some examples of user selected fonts and how they render in your browser. similar issues occur in email. All fonts are not "web safe" and my browser only renders about 2 of the cursive fonts listed as they are shown in the image. I know the issue is not exactly as you describe. but it does illustrate not all fonts work.

The same organization publish this page https://www.w3schools.com/cssref/css_websafe_fonts.php of web safe fonts and realistically you should keep you email to only those fonts as there is no guarantee when folk will see, but those can be assumed to be on most computers and phones, regardless of manufacturer or operating system.

Who is the W3C? In short The World Wide Web Consortium is the main international standards organization for the World Wide Web. Founded in 1994 by Tim Berners-Lee, the consortium is made up of member organizations that maintain full-time staff working together in the development of standards for the World Wide Web. See the full Wikipedia article for additional detail. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web_Consortium
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
First thing I'd do is use the provider's webmail interface, if available, to see if the folder is still there as either the old or new name. While there, I'd make another, temporary, folder and copy all those messages into it for safe keeping. The copies can be deleted later.

(This is the Windows version...) In Thunderbird, right-click on the account name in the left pane, and choose "Subscribe". You'll see a list of all folders. Click the "Refresh" button. Hopefully the missing folder will now be listed. Make sure there's check mark by it. Choose OK.

If the missing folder now appears and it has all the expected messages, you can delete the temporary folder.

content:
Create, or re-use, the password that works for accessing the account in webmail, then remove all entries for the account from Saved Passwords in Settings. Restart TB and enter the (working) password at the prompt, and check the box to have it saved.

A password is required for TWC accounts with normal password authentication:

incoming IMAP: mail.twc.com, 993, SSL/TLS, normal password, email address

outgoing SMTP: mail.twc.com, 587, STARTTLS, normal password, email address

https://www.spectrum.net/support/internet/mobile-email-setup
creator: sfhowes

content:
You'll need to clarify some things. Thunderbird is not an "account", it's an email agent, that is, a program that interfaces with your email servers and allows you to send and receive email. What happens when you try to retrieve email? Do you get any error messages? What about when you try to send?

You can try to verify your email settings, which should be available from your email provider (maybe on their Help web site.) You're looking for:

IMAP or POP3 server name IMAP or POP3 port number user name (usually your email address) connection security setting (SSL, TLS, STARTTLS) authentication method (normal password, OAuth2, etc.s)

SMTP Server Name: smtp.comcast.net SMTP Port: 465 Authentication method Connection Security

Check that information against what you already find in the Accounts Settings.

creator: davidsk

content: For IMAP accounts, uncheck 'Keep messages...' in the Sync. & Storage section of Account Settings to download headers only. When a message is opened, it is stored in the cache, and retrieved from there next time unless the cache is emptied. With this option, the profile folder has no mbox files in the account folders, just index .msf files.
creator: sfhowes

content: Could you please tell me the location where Thunderbird might have created the folder, and how I can safely clean it without losing any data?
creator: valinviet

content: Help/Troubleshooting Info, Profile Folder, Open Directory (Win: Folder), to open the profile folder. The account folders are subfolders of ImapMail, e.g. ImapMail/imap.gmail.com. There you will see files like Inbox (the mbox file, no extension) and Inbox.msf, if messages bodies were previously downloaded. Close TB and move the mbox temporarily to a separate location if you wish to only download headers. Restart TB and confirm messages are opening correctly, and that the mbox file doesn't reappear.
